displaytitle: Frederick de Vries with Goltzius’s Dog
dimensions: plate (sheet trimmed to plate): 35.8 × 26.7 cm (14 1/8 × 10 1/2 in.)
creditline: Bequest of Junius S. Morgan, Class of 1888
markings: Collector's stamp, lower center: Edme-Antoine Durand (Lugt 741)
inscribed:
Initialed and dated in plate lower left: Privil. Sa. Cae. M. Anno 1597 / HG

Dedication in cartouche at bottom center: Theodorico Frisio Pictor egrogio / aput Venetos amicitiæ et filij absentis / repræsentandi gratia D.D. [squiggle] 

Two Latin distichs in margin, left and right: Quid tabula hae capiat, fors non capis: en tibi paucis / Mentom, simpluitas quorit amat[?] fideom. / Fida canis, simplex[?] puor, quos Goltzius apto / Vivero Phidiaca foeit in cre manu.   

Signed in plate in margin, lower right corner: P. Seriverius

titles.title: Frederick de Vries with Goltzius’s Dog

makers.displaydate: 1558–1617; born Mülbracht, Netherlands; died Haarlem, Netherlands
makers.displaymaker: Hendrick Goltzius, 1558–1617; born Mülbracht, Netherlands; died Haarlem, Netherlands

texts.textentryhtml: Edme-Antoine Durand [1768-1835, Lugt 741]; sale of his collection, Paris, January 25, 1836, lot 62. Junius S. Morgan [1867-1932]; bequeathed to Princeton University Art Museum, 1932.

Goltzius, a leading Dutch engraver of his time, was the guardian of Frederick de Vries while his father, the painter Dirck de Vries, was away in Venice. In this elaborate print, Goltzius depicts his charge climbing onto the artist’s dog, playfully evoking a knight mounting his trusty steed. The engraving is thus a double portrait—of young Frederick and of Goltzius’s spaniel. As the artist explains in the Latin inscription, simplicity (the innocent boy) seeks and loves faithfulness (the dog). In seventeenth-century writings, the dog was described as a teacher charged with looking after man. Here, the dog stands in for the artist himself, as devoted instructor and guardian of the child.

bibliography.boilertext: F.W.H. Hollstein, "Goltzius-Heemskerck," Dutch and Flemish etchings, engravings, and woodcuts, ca. 1450-1700, (Amsterdam: M. Hertzberger, 1953).
